Question Text: Which of the following is an example of a network layer (layer 3) protocol in the five-layer TCP/IP model?
Choices:
a. IP
b. Ethernet
c. UDP
d. TCP
LLM Explanation: IP (Internet Protocol) is the network/internet layer (layer 3 in the five-layer TCP/IP model). It provides logical addressing and routing of packets between hosts. Ethernet is a link-layer (layer 2) technology, while TCP and UDP are transport-layer (layer 4) protocols.

Question Text: Which of these is an example of something that works on the application layer (layer 5 of the five-layer TCP/IP model)?
Choices:
a. A router
b. A browser
c. UDP
d. An ethernet cable
LLM Explanation: A web browser is an application that operates at the application layer of the TCP/IP (five-layer) model, using application protocols like HTTP/HTTPS. A router functions at the network layer (IP), UDP is a transport-layer protocol, and an Ethernet cable is a physical-layer medium.

Question Text: Which layer of the five layer TCP/IP model deals with cabling and connectors?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The application layer
LLM Explanation: The physical layer (the lowest layer in the five-layer TCP/IP/Internet model) is responsible for the physical transmission medium — cabling, connectors, voltages, signal encoding and the actual bit-level transmission over wires, fiber or wireless. Cabling and connectors are therefore dealt with at the physical layer.

Question Text: Which level of the TCP/IP five-layer model does a router operate on?
Choices:
a. The data link layer
b. The transport layer
c. The application layer
d. The network layer
LLM Explanation: Routers operate at the network layer of the TCP/IP model. They forward packets based on network (IP) addresses and use routing protocols (e.g., OSPF, BGP) to determine paths. Data-link devices (switches/bridges) work at the data link layer, transport-layer functions are end-to-end (TCP/UDP), and application-layer functions are above transport.

Question Text: On which layer are Ethernet standards and some wireless technologies operating?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The data link layer
LLM Explanation: Ethernet (IEEE 802.3) is primarily an OSI Layer 2 technology (data link) responsible for framing and MAC addressing (though 802 standards also define PHY specifics). Wireless LAN standards (e.g., IEEE 802.11) likewise include a MAC (data link) layer. Therefore the correct layer is the data link layer (Layer 2).

Question Text: Which of these allows connections from many devices and inspects the contents of ethernet protocol data?
Choices:
a. A hub
b. A collision domain
c. A cable
d. A switch
LLM Explanation: A network switch connects many devices and inspects Ethernet frame contents (Layer 2), e.g., MAC addresses, to make forwarding decisions. A hub merely repeats signals (Layer 1) and does not inspect frame contents; a collision domain and a cable are not devices that perform frame inspection.

Question Text: What does LAN stand for?
Choices:
a. Local area network
b. Little area network
c. Large area network
d. Locally available network
LLM Explanation: LAN stands for "Local Area Network," a network that connects computers and devices within a limited geographic area (such as a home, office, or campus). The other choices (little, large, locally available) are incorrect expansions of the acronym.

Question Text: What's a router?
Choices:
a. A physical layer device that prevents crosstalk
b. A device that knows how to forward data between independent networks.
c. A more advanced version of a switch
d. A physical layer device that allows connections for many computers at once
LLM Explanation: A router is a network-layer device that forwards packets between independent networks using routing tables and protocols (e.g., IP routing). It connects separate networks and makes per-packet forwarding decisions based on network addresses. The other choices describe physical-layer hubs or incorrect notions (not a physical-layer crosstalk device, nor merely an "advanced switch").

Question Text: Which of these is a server?
Choices:
a. A device operating on the data link layer that connects many devices together and inspects ethernet protocol data
b. A device that forwards data between multiple networks
c. Something receiving data from something providing data
d. Something providing data to something requesting the data
LLM Explanation: A server in networking is an entity that provides data or services to clients that request them — option (d). Option (a) describes a layer‑2 switch/bridge that inspects Ethernet frames, option (b) describes a router (forwards between networks), and option (c) describes a receiver or client rather than a server.

Question Text: What kind of wiring is in cables that communicate in voltage changes that are received by the receiving device as ones and zeros?
Choices:
a. Fiber
b. Aluminum
c. Gold
d. Copper
LLM Explanation: Copper wiring (e.g., twisted-pair or coaxial copper cables) transmits data as electrical signals — changes in voltage/current that receivers interpret as binary ones and zeros. Optical fiber uses light pulses, and gold is used for plating rather than as the main conductor; aluminum is not the common medium for standard digital network cabling.

Question Text: What modulation type is used for computer networks?
Choices:
a. RJ45
b. Simplex communication
c. Line coding
d. Line crimping
LLM Explanation: Line coding is the modulation method used in computer networks to represent digital data as electrical or optical signals on the transmission medium (examples: NRZ, Manchester, MLT-3, PAM-5). The other choices are a connector (RJ45), a communication direction mode (simplex), and a crimping action/tool, so they are not modulation types.

Question Text: What is the difference between full duplex and half duplex?
Choices:
a. Half duplex occurs when hubs are in use; full duplex occurs when switches are in use.
b. Full duplex allows communications in two directions at the same time; half duplex means that only one side can communicate at a time.
c. Full duplex is a form of simplex communications.
d. Full duplex is slower than half duplex.
LLM Explanation: Full duplex means communication can occur in both directions simultaneously on the link; half duplex means only one direction at a time (transmit or receive). Option a is a common association (hubs are typically half-duplex, switches support full-duplex) but is not the definition and not universally true in all configurations. Options c and d are incorrect (full duplex is not simplex, and it is not inherently slower).

Question Text: The ____________ consists of devices and is responsible for sending signals between devices.
Choices:
a. network layer
b. data link layer
c. physical layer
d. modulation
LLM Explanation: The physical layer is the OSI/TCP-IP layer responsible for the transmission and reception of raw bitstreams over a physical medium and consists of physical devices and media (cables, repeaters, hubs, NIC electrical/optical interfaces) that send signals between devices. Other choices refer to higher-layer functions (data link frames, network routing) or a process (modulation).

Question Text: What is the most common type of cabling used for connecting computing devices?
Choices:
a. Power Cable
b. Twisted Pair Cable
c. VGA Cable
d. SATA Cable
LLM Explanation: Twisted-pair cabling (UTP/STP, e.g., Cat5e/Cat6) is the prevalent cabling type for connecting computing devices on local area networks and for many device interconnections via Ethernet. It is far more widely deployed for networking than VGA (video), SATA (internal storage), or power cables (which supply power but are not primarily used for data connectivity).

Question Text: Which of the following are category types of Twisted Pair Ethernet cable? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP).
b. Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP).
c. Shielded Twisted Pair (STP).
d. USB Cable
LLM Explanation: Twisted-pair Ethernet cables are commonly classified by their shielding and construction: Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP), Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP) (sometimes called F/UTP or screened), and Shielded Twisted Pair (STP). USB is a connector/cable standard for peripheral devices, not a category of twisted-pair Ethernet cable.

Question Text: How many octets are there in a MAC address?
LLM Explanation: A MAC (Media Access Control) address is 48 bits long, which equals 6 octets (6 × 8 = 48).

Question Text: What address is used for Ethernet broadcasts?
LLM Explanation: Ethernet uses the MAC address consisting of all 1 bits as the broadcast address, written in hex as FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF. This frame is accepted by every station on the local LAN. The other choices are not the all-ones broadcast (00:00:00:00:00:00 is the all-zero address used in special cases, 11:11:... is arbitrary, and FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:00 is not all ones).

Question Text: What is a cyclical redundancy check?
Choices:
a. A way for two computers to synchronize their clocks.
b. The actual data being transported by an Ethernet frame.
c. A technique that allows for multiple logical LANs to operate on the same equipment.
d. A mathematical calculation used to ensure that all data arrived intact.
LLM Explanation: A cyclic redundancy check (CRC) is an error-detection technique: the sender computes a checksum using polynomial division of the data, appends the CRC (remainder) to the frame, and the receiver recomputes and compares to detect corruption. It is not clock sync, payload data, or VLAN functionality.

Question Text: Which of the following are ways for transmitting data at the Ethernet level? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Multicast
b. Duplex
c. Broadcast
d. Unicast
LLM Explanation: Ethernet frames can be sent to a single destination MAC (unicast), to all hosts on the LAN using the broadcast MAC (broadcast), or to a group of hosts using multicast MAC addresses. "Duplex" describes link operation mode (half/full duplex) and is not a frame-addressing/transmission type.

Question Text: Which of the following are parts of an Ethernet frame? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Data payload
c. EtherType field
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: An Ethernet frame includes a preamble (and Start Frame Delimiter), MAC header fields (destination and source addresses), an EtherType/Length field, the data payload (payload), and a Frame Check Sequence (FCS). "Broadcast" is not a frame field — it is a possible value of the destination MAC address (e.g., ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff), not a separate part of the frame format.
